intro: Phacelia malvifolia var. loasifolia, commonly known as the Loasifolia phacelia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its showy, violet-blue flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun, making it well-suited for arid environments. Its leaves are usually hairy and arranged oppositely along the stems, contributing to its distinctive appearance. This variety is often cultivated for its ornamental value and ability to attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
